title: 108_hr5217
content:
The "Railroad Security and Public Awareness Act of 2004" includes provisions for a rail worker security training program and public awareness initiatives. It also mandates railroad security upgrades. The "Railroad Security and Public Awareness Act of 2004" mandates the development of detailed guidance for a rail worker security training program within 60 days of enactment. The program must include elements such as determining seriousness of occurrences, crew communication, appropriate responses to threats, use of protective devices, evacuation procedures, and understanding terrorist psychology. The Railroad Security and Public Awareness Act of 2004 requires railroad carriers to develop a rail worker security training program within 60 days of guidance issuance. The program must cover threat conditions, tunnel evacuation procedures, and comply with Transportation Security Directives. The Railroad Security and Public Awareness Act of 2004 mandates railroad carriers to create a security training program approved by the Secretary. The program must be completed within 180 days and updated regularly to address new security threats. Grants are available for railroads, hazardous materials shippers, and owners. The Railroad Security and Public Awareness Act of 2004 mandates security training programs for railroad carriers, hazardous materials shippers, and rail car owners. $250,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006 for implementation. Front-line workers are defined as rail employees with daily access to rail operations and passengers. SEC. 3. PUBLIC AWARENESS.

Within 90 days of this Act's enactment, the Secretary of Homeland Security must create a national plan for public outreach to enhance awareness of railroad system security measures for the general public, passengers, and employees. The plan will also educate railroad carriers and employees on available technologies, research efforts, and Federal funding sources for security improvements. Implementation of the plan is required within 9 months.

SEC. 4. RAILROAD SECURITY UPGRADES. Security Improvement Grants authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security for railroads, hazardous materials shippers, rail car owners, universities, colleges, research centers, and State/local governments to prevent/respond to terrorism, sabotage, or security threats. Grants cover technologies for tank car vulnerability reduction, bridge/tunnel inspection, critical communications/electric power redundancy for secure railroad operations. The curr_chunk focuses on security measures for railroad operations, including control systems, hazardous material transportation, passenger stations, public awareness campaigns, intelligence sharing, train tracking, additional police and security officers, and provisions from Transportation Security Directives. The Transportation Security Administration authorized $250,000,000 for fiscal year 2006 under section 114 of title 49, United States Code for security purposes.
